'''Diunna Greenleaf''' (born October 6, 1957)<ref name="Ancestry"/> is an [[African American]] [[blues]] singer and songwriter.

At the 2014 [[Blues Music Award]]s, Greenleaf won the Koko Taylor Award (Traditional Blues Female), beating fellow nominees Teeny Tucker, [[Lavelle White]], [[Trudy Lynn]], and [[Zora Young]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref>

==Life and career==
'''Diunna Fay Greenleaf''' was born in [[Houston]], [[Texas]], United States.<ref name="Ancestry"/> Her parents, Ben and Mary Ella Greenleaf (nee Travis), were religiously devout and involved in [[gospel music]].<ref name="Down"/> Her early musical influences included [[Sam Cooke]], [[Sister Rosetta Tharpe]], [[Koko Taylor]], and [[Aretha Franklin]].<ref name="Diunna"/> Before her musical career, Greenleaf obtained a [[First professional degree|degree]] in Mass Communications at the [[Prairie View A&M University]].<ref name="Ancestry"/><ref name="Down">{{cite book
| first= Charles Roger
| last= Wood
| year= 2003
| title= Down in Houston: Bayou City Blues
| edition= 19th
| publisher= [[University of Texas Press]] 
| location= [[Austin, Texas]]
| page= 245
| isbn= 0-292-79159-3}}</ref>

Greenleaf and her backing band, Blue Mercy, have performed on the international stage for a number of years.<ref name="Diunna"/> In 2005, they took  part and triumphed at the [[International Blues Challenge]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]].<ref name="Toro">{{cite web|url=http://deltoroblues.wordpress.com/about/ |title=About Jonn 'Del Toro' Richardson - The Texas Bull |publisher=Deltoroblues.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref>

She was President of the Houston Blues Society for three years, becoming the first woman to undertake that role. Greenleaf initiated the now annual Houston Blues Society Founders Day, and continues to support the Blues in Schools Program. She was also one of the founders of the Friends of Blues Montgomery County.<ref name="Diunna"/>

She performed as a [[backing vocalist]] for [[Pinetop Perkins]], on his segment of the [[50th Annual Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] winning album, ''[[Last of the Great Mississippi Delta Bluesmen: Live in Dallas]]'' (2007).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/last-of-the-great-mississippi-delta-bluesmen-live-in-dallas-r1096268/charts-awards |title=Last of the Great Mississippi Delta Bluesmen: Live in Dallas |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=2012-05-20}}</ref> The same year Greenleaf and Blue Mercy issued their debut [[studio album]], ''Cotton Field to Coffee House''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pastblues.com/view-action-89.html?en=Diunna+Greenleaf |title=PastBlues Your blues |publisher=Pastblues.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref>

In 2008 at the [[Blues Music Award]]s, Greenleaf won the 'Best New Artist Debut' award for ''Cotton Field to Coffee House''.<ref name="Toro"/> At the same ceremony the following year, she was nominated for the 'Koko Taylor Award (Traditional Blues Female)'. In 2012, Greenleaf was nominated again for the 'Koko Taylor Award', and in the 'Traditional Blues Album' category for ''Trying to Hold On''.<ref name="Diunna">{{cite web|url=http://www.diunna.com/ |title=Diunna Greenleaf - Diunna Greenleaf and Blue Mercy |publisher=Diunna.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref> The album included fourteen songs, of which Greenleaf wrote ten and co-wrote another. The album was recorded in [[Tempe, Arizona]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acousticmusic.com/fame/p07441.htm |title=FAME Review: Diunna Greenleaf - Trying To Hold On |publisher=Acousticmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref>

[[Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne]]'s most recent release, ''Rollin' with the Blues Boss'' (2014), included guest vocal contributions from Greenleaf and [[Eric Bibb]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Steve Leggett |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/rollin-with-the-blues-boss-mw0002629844 |title=Rollin' with the Blues Boss - Kenny "Blues Boss" Wayne | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date=2014-04-22 |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref>

==Festivals==
Greenleaf has performed at many [[music festival]]s. These include the Blues to Bop Festival in Lugano, Switzerland, the [[Montreal International Jazz Festival]] (2009),<ref name="Mont">{{cite web|url=http://www.montrealjazzfest.com/artists/artist.aspx?id=7045 |title=Artist : Diunna Greenleaf - Festival International de Jazz de Montréal |publisher=Montrealjazzfest.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref> the Bern Jazz Festival,<ref name="Diunna"/> the [[King Biscuit Blues Festival|Arkansas Blues and Heritage Festival]] (2007),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.earlyblues.com/down_the_dirt_road5.htm |title=Down the Dirt Road Part 5 |publisher=Earlyblues.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref> [[Boundary Waters Blues Festival]], [[Sarasota Blues Fest]] (2008), [[Notodden Blues Festival]] (2008), [[Long Beach Blues Festival]] (2009), the DC Blues Festival (2010),<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://inabluemood.blogspot.co.uk/2010/09/diunna-greenleaf-rocked-dc-blues.html |title=In a Blue Mood: Diunna Greenleaf Rocked the DC Blues Festival |publisher=Inabluemood.blogspot.co.uk |date=2010-09-06 |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref> the Tinner Hill Blues Festival (2012),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestatetheatre.com/events/e1540.xml |title=Welcome to The State Theatre |publisher=Thestatetheatre.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref> and the proposed [[Bikes Blues and BBQ]] (2014).<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://bbqbluesfest.com/music.asp |title=Motorcyle event | Blues Festival | Elizabethtown, Kentucky |publisher=Bbqbluesfest.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-17}}</ref>
